Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reform and Innovation in an Urban Criminal Justice System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is an ethnographic study of new modes of reform being tested in the New Orleans criminal justice system. As the city government faces growing challenges -- financial, moral, legal, and infrastructural -- to its current practices of incarceration, this research asks what different understandings of justice and forms of change can be discussed and acted upon locally, and how these are being taken up in the national conversation on criminal justice reform.

The research will be based on 12 months of participant-observation, mapping exercises, and interviews with participants in two new collaborative projects. The first is a group of nonprofit and activist organizations advocating for criminal justice reform in the city. The second is a regular meeting of representatives from criminal justice agencies in "working groups" to discuss and evaluate current reforms. These two sites have the potential to provide new insight into the project of criminal justice reform, as they provide a regular space in which organizations and individuals accustomed to operating independently attempt to coordinate efforts, and in so doing articulate their own institutional, political, and ethical stakes.

By providing ethnographic insight into the everyday work of criminal justice reform as it is carried out by government officials, reform advocates, and state employees, this project will situate criminal justice reform within local and national political economies of justice, and provide a robust understanding of the challenges and possibilities presented by collaboration between government (local, state, and federal) and civil society around criminal justice reform in the United States. This project aims to contribute to scholarly conversations on crime, law, and governance; the anthropology of race; and Americanist anthropology, as well as to the growing national conversation on criminal justice reform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research for this project consisted primarily of participant-observation and semi-structured interviews in several non-profit and community groups working in New Orleans to reform the local jail. The jail, Orleans Parish Prison (OPP) is currently being governed by a federal consent decree after a class-action lawsuit successfully established that conditions in the jail are unconstitutional. The City of New Orleans is also invested in creating policy changes aimed at reducing the number of people being held in the jail on any given day. The co-PI for this research project spent over a year in New Orleans studying the two projects of improving conditions in the jail and reducing the jail's size. The dissertation will focus on several key themes that have emerged over the course of the research.

            First, as a study of a local jail, the resulting dissertation will highlight key differences between jail and prison reform, often overlooked in national conversations. The primary purpose of jail is to house individuals who have been accused but not convicted of a crime, and to house individuals who have been convicted and sentenced to a short term of detention (usually less than one year). In New Orleans, as in much of the rest of the United States, the pretrial population in the jail is made up in large part of people who are incarcerated because they cannot afford the bail set in their case. The dissertation will explore the efforts to decrease the extent to which New Orleans incarcerates its poor, and will highlight the ways in which the continued practice of setting a price on pretrial freedom creates barriers both to reducing the jail's size and improving its conditions.

            A key outcome of the research was the discovery of the extent to which decision-making around criminal justice policy is dependent upon quantitative analysis of the jail population. However, the production of numbers on the jail population is not a simple task. The dissertation will show how such numbers are produced, and will illuminate some of the ways in which numerical "facts" about the jail are produced by processes that are deeply social in nature. It will also trace the selective deployment of these numbers in the political process of making decisions about the jail's future.

            The dissertation will also further explore the connection between incarceration and mental health. Although much has been written about the fact that jails in the United States today are often also "hospitals of last resort" for individuals suffering from mental illness, the research for this project revealed that the prevalence of mental illness in jail settings is in no small part a result of the traumatizing and violent nature of jail itself. The dissertation will discuss the ways in which incarceration traumatizes not only those individuals who are themselves incarcerated but also their friends, families, lawyers, and social workers.

            Finally, the research revealed deep connections between incarceration and the history of slavery in New Orleans, the history of Jim Crow racism, and the more recent trauma of Hurricane Katrina.  The dissertation will explore the ways in which the racial violence of each of those historical moments is present in discussions of jail reform today. It will also interrogate how the organizational structures and funding economies of both legal and policy reform can unintentionally perpetuate this violence, even as they work to end it.
